content: Just saying "Whats up" everyone. I've been so in and out of Backdrop over the past year or so but I just got the GO to move a very large site to backdrop over the next year (huzzah). So I'll do my best to participate more here...
@Rob Feature Yay! I've been wondering about you and your Backdrop work. Congrats on the site!

Thanks! Yeah, Im a little nervous because its big. Tons of custom functionality, API modules, etc. Whats the biggest/most robust site that's launched on backdrop? I feel like unless theres some huge ones, my project may be a first really big test :)
Sounds exciting
Maybe. Unless its a disaster :)
i kept emphasizing to them I wanted at least a year to port it from D7. Luckily they got on board.

Whats the biggest/most robust site that's launched on backdrop?

Good question. We should probably have some ready examples of large(ish) sites. None of my Backdrop Sites would qualify as large. I bet @jenlampton has some contenders.
Yeah, I figured the core folks probably launched some stuff I didn't know about.
I'm sure any large sites would warrant a listing on https://backdropcms.org/showcase Having said that, you can't easily tell which ones are 'large' or not...

Whats the biggest/most robust site that's launched on backdrop?

"Biggest" and "most robust" are different attributes; might even be anti-correllated. :wink:

Wondering what's the best way to quantify "biggest". Total number of contrib+custom modules? Total number of nodes?
@bugfolder yeah, I guess I'd say define it however you want :) I haven't looked real hard, but most of what I've seen have been smaller sites for nonprofts, personal sites, portfiolio sites, etc.

The site I'll be doing has about 1/4million nodes and at least 10 api-oriented / service modules, ios app integration, blah blah ,plus many dozens more standard modules. I dont know the visitors per day, but its quite a few.
Mostly I'm wondering how scared I should be :) But then I tell myself: Backdrop is just D7..but better.
Yeah, number of nodes/DB size would be a good indication of a website's 'size' I guess.

BWPanda said:

Yeah, number of nodes/DB size would be a good indication of a website's 'size' I guess.

I'm assuming there was nothing changed in Backdrop that would negatively affect database performance for larger numbers of nodes like this (?)
@Rob Feature I can't say on the DB side of things, but I will say that hosting environments can create a night and day difference for performance.

@Phil Ward Thanks, yeah, not worried about hosting. Running on a dedicated server with varnish, memcache, and the works. (getting those caching modules working will be part of the challenge of this, if theyre not already ported)
I don't think Redis has been ported but might look at that as a caching alternative. (It's available for D7).
We continue to see an ongoing stream of modules being ported, pretty much every week new ones arrive.
@StPaulTim Yeah, part of my question about 'big sites' was I know theyre the only ones using things like Varnish or Solr, both things I'll need to get ported if they're not already.
Don't be scared... OK, I did never create sites with 1000's of nodes so far, but some with 100's of nodes, and Backdrop handles them much better than D7 handled similar projects:-)

We have this topic in the forum: https://forum.backdropcms.org/forum/can-backdrop-handle-large-websites

I wonder if we shouldn't create a forum topic for folks to share examples of "large" or "complex" websites and talk about them?

@StPaulTim Good post, thanks for sharing. I always wondered about the 'small to medium size' claim as well..wondered if they took something out for big sites that ran on D7....but I realize that comment is more about the target audience than the capabilities of the system itself.

but I realize that comment is more about the target audience than the capabilities of the system itself.

Well put!

I wonder if we shouldn't create a forum topic for folks to share examples of "large" or "complex" websites and talk about them?

We talked about adding these onto backdropcms.og as "case studies". I have a few sites I'd call large -- with tens of thousands of nodes. And I have some that are complex, but I still don't really know how to compare two sites to determine which is the biggest project. Usually that's determined by how much work I have to do, and some of my large+complex sites are the easiest to maintain :)

Whats the biggest/most robust site that's launched on backdrop?

I seem to recall that question being asked sometime in the last 2 or 3 weeks.

I don't think Redis has been ported but might look at that as a caching alternative. (It's available for D7).

@Joseph Flatt ported the Redis module several months ago, but he hasn't tagged a release: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/redis
There is no module for memcache.

backdrop-contrib/redis
Provides integration with the Redis key-value store. - backdrop-contrib/redis

Yeah, part of my question about 'big sites' was I know theyre the only ones using things like Varnish or Solr, both things I'll need to get ported if they're not already.

There is this module for Solr, though I don't know if it's enough: https://backdropcms.org/project/search_api_solr and https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/search_api_solr (same module on b.org and Github)
AFAIK, you don't need a module for Varnish, as it sits in front of the HTTPD server.

backdrop-contrib/search_api_solr
This module provides an implementation of the Search API which uses an Apache Solr search server for indexing and searching. - backdrop-contrib/search_api_solr

BTW, it only takes a minute to go to https://github.com/backdrop-contrib and type in a module name to see if anyone has started something. I generally go there before or instead of going to https://backdropcms.org/modules

Backdrop CMS contributed projects
Join the group at https://github.com/backdrop-ops/contrib to add your own! - Backdrop CMS contributed projects

Exciting news @Rob Feature :tada: ...perhaps if you have the time and energy you can start a min-blog series, as some sort of diary of the move to Backdrop over the course of the year. You can make notes of the progress you are making, any blockers and workarounds/compromises along the way, hidden gems or life-saving features in Backdrop, and your overall experience in general.

Thanks everyone. I'm sorta in the 'mind being blown' portion of this project at this point. There's probably going to be months of just visualizing how things are going to work and minor tests here and there, taking notes on what modules exist, alternatives, etc. I'll see what I can do about documenting the whole thing once I get past the 'wrap my mind around it' stage.

TBH I imagine it is well in the best interest of Backdrop as a project to see a large site build succeed, for potential hesitant clients in the future. I'd be happy to help start new module ports going if you need.
@docwilmot Thanks I appreciate that. My question, down the road, was going to be "what developers are available for hire" to port complex modules that I may not be able to do myself. :)
Dont recall if paid work has come up here before, but I dont imagine everyone would refuse :smile:
I'm all for helping backdrop by helping people get paid to work on it, when possible. :)

@Rob Feature I'm sure you'll find the conversation that @Phil Ward has started in https://backdrop.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/218635-Backdrop/topic/Funding.20Backdrop.20Development very interesting :wink: ...we plan to discuss this matter further with community members during the upcoming Backdrop Live event: https://events.backdropcms.org
@Rob Feature I'd be happy to help in some capacity regarding getting paid to port modules.

@Herb Awesome, thanks. Itll be months from now, no doubt...but I'll certainly put out a call here, with specific modules that I need, when the time comes. Im mostly happy to here there's folks who are interested in jumping in!
We've been moving client sites to stop using Solr if they don't really need it, though sounds like yours will need it. The d7 module doesn't support the stable Solr releases however
All through the process I'll be asking "Do we need this module? Should we use something else?" so your input will be really helpful when I get there.
@bugfolder might know more about search API and Solr

Nice thing about solr, it's info is independent of the site, so choosing to move off of it wouldn't be detrimental.

There's a fremium service I've run across recently that might be a great alternative (would need contrib created for it I think)

https://www.elastic.co/

Free and Open Search: The Creators of Elasticsearch, ELK & Kibana | Elastic
Retain and search more data with searchable snapshots on low-cost object stores + a new cold data tier in 7.11.
@Herb I probably ought to know more about them, but alas, don't.

RE: People getting paid to work on modules that need porting and/or development, in general I think it's great. It's a version of working the time to port/develop modules in to a project estimate and it helps the project in general. I do think it's a valid concern to make sure that the money doesn't dictate the direction of the project at large, but it seems like that's a pretty widely shared assumption. I have heard others express that they are open to working on modules but since it's a hobby they don't want to be paid -- maybe in that case the money that is under discussion (if any is available) can be contributed to the Backdrop project instead of the individual.
